intro: Trachyspermum matthewii, commonly known as Indian cumin, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic, branched stems and compound leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its seeds, often used as a spice, have a warm, earthy flavor and are valued in traditional cuisines. Trachyspermum matthewii is also noted for its medicinal properties, with potential uses in digestive and respiratory health.
